instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's killing me, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Working on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that had some "rough" handling by someone prior to me getting it. Replaced ~10 components that were broken-off/missing (mostly non-critical caps/resistors, etc). Confirmed all parts are now present on the board, but I can't restore power, with the following symptoms:

1. Board has <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> all present and stable/normal, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0v.
2. Pin 6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is .8v, which I believe is normal, but pin 23 is 0v.
3. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present and stable, despite pin 23 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> not being present (this confuses me).
4. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present and stable (3.45v)
5. Charger light is solid green the entire time, but it flickers ever so slightly, as if it's trying to power on. All SMC power lines stable/normal.
6. No shorts on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
7. Replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (twice--three total chips), <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>, no change

I'm not sure where to go from here. All help appreciated--thanks!

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's killing me, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Resistance to ground at L7220/60?
Do not expect PGOOD signal before voltages are generated...

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's killing me, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply! I guess I was confused on the order of the signals; that makes sense that pgood wouldn't show up until both 3v3 and 5v were active. I believe I thought that the PGOOD signal came before 5v and 3v3 were sent out, but that doesn't make sense.

RTG at L7220 is 15.42 kOhms. At L7260 it's 31 kOhms.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's killing me, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: If there is 0.8V on pin 6 the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is being told to turn on. If PPBUS is present at <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> there should be <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. If not the problem is in the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> circuit, check all voltages, resistors and caps.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's killing me, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Thanks, Duke. Pin 6 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> is 0v. I get <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_3V3S5</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>) on pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7241</CAPACITOR>, so <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> is getting power. I won't lie, I've never been very comfortable with how MOSFETs work ([I]I've read so much information on P-type vs N-type, but I don't understand which voltages come and go in some of the Apple schematics; they always seem to look different than the sample diagrams online...more complex; I get gate/source/drain, but the Apple schematics always look so much more complex[/I]), but since <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL> are both gate signals (and output low/high MOSFET driver signals from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>), does this mean <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is still at fault? At <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, pins 10 and 12 are both 0v.

threads.title: Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that's killing me, no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
There is nothing to measure at the output FETs just switching signals so multimeter won't make much sense.
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is being told to turn on by the 0.8V on pin 6 but there is no output. If there is no short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> then the issue is around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, not much more I can say about it. Check if LDO outputs of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> are all working too (vref/vreg).
